qas.question: What was the longest-lived Macintosh in Apple's history while it was in production?
How long did the Mac Plus remain in production, unchanged?

answers.text: just over four years and ten months

qas.question: In 1986, what did Apple introduce to allow developers to create software for Macintosh on Macintosh?
What did Apple's HyerCard and MultiFinder add to the Macintosh?
After their unveiling in 1987, what did Apple begin bundling with every Macintosh?
What was the shortest-lived Macintosh in Apple's history while it was in production?

plausible_answers.text: just over four years and ten months

qas.question: How long did the Mac Minus remain in production, unchanged?
In 1984, what did Apple introduce to allow developers to create software for Macintosh on Macintosh?
What did Microsoft's HyerCard and MultiFinder add to the Macintosh?
After their unveiling in 1978, what did Apple begin bundling with every Macintosh?

context: Apple released the Macintosh Plus on January 10, 1986, for a price of US$2,600. It offered one megabyte of RAM, easily expandable to four megabytes by the use of socketed RAM boards. It also featured a SCSI parallel interface, allowing up to seven peripherals—such as hard drives and scanners—to be attached to the machine. Its floppy drive was increased to an 800 kB capacity. <a0_0><b5_0>The Mac Plus<b5_0/><a0_0/> was an immediate success and remained in production, unchanged, until October 15, 1990; on sale for <a1_0><b6_0>just over four years and ten months<b6_0/><a1_0/>, it was the longest-lived Macintosh in Apple's history. In September 1986, Apple introduced the <a2_0><b7_0>Macintosh Programmer's Workshop<b7_0/><a2_0/>, or MPW, an application that allowed software developers to create software for Macintosh on Macintosh, rather than cross compiling from a Lisa. In August 1987, Apple unveiled <a4_0><b9_0>HyperCard and MultiFinder<b9_0/><a4_0/>, which added <a3_0><b8_0>cooperative multitasking<b8_0/><a3_0/> to the Macintosh. Apple began bundling both with every Macintosh.
